By a trinomial we mean a polynomial of the form $f=T_0^{l_0}+T_1^{l_1}+T_2^{l_2}$. A trinomial hypersurface $X$ is the zero set $\{f=0\}$ in the affine space ${\mathbb K}^n$. Clearly, $X$ is an irreducible normal affine variety of dimension $n-1$.

If $A$ is a ${\mathbb K}$-algebra, a derivation $D\colon A\to A$ is a linear map satisfying the Leibniz rule $D(ab)=D(a)b+aD(b)$ for all $a,b\in A$. A derivation is called locally nilpotent if for each $a\in A$ there exists $m\in{\mathbb Z}_{>0}$ such that $D^m(a)=0$. An algebra $A$ is called rigid if it admits no nonzero locally nilpotent derivations.

An affine algebraic variety $X$ is rigid if the algebra of regular functions ${\mathbb K}[X]$ is. It is well known that locally nilpotent derivations of the algebra ${\mathbb K}[X]$ are in one-to-one correspondence with regular actions ${\mathbb G}_a\times X\to X$ of the group ${\mathbb G}_a:=({\mathbb K},+)$, cf. \cite[Section~1.5]{F}. In particular, $X$ is rigid means that $X$ admits no nontrivial ${\mathbb G}_a$-action.

We say that an affine variety $X$ is factorial if the algebra ${\mathbb K}[X]$ is a unique factorization domain. Returning to trinomial, for each $i=0,1,2$ let $d_i:=\text{gcd}(l_{i1},\ldots,l_{in_i})$.
Below we assume that $n_il_{i1}>1$ for $i=0,1,2$ or, equivalently, $f$ does not contain a linear term; otherwise the hypersurface $X$ is isomorphic to the affine space ${\mathbb K}^{n-1}$. Under this assumption, the trinomial hypersurface $X$ is factorial if and only if any two of $d_0,d_1,d_2$ are coprime \cite[Theorem~1.1~(ii)]{HH}.

$T_0^{l_0}+T_1^{l_1}+T_2^{l_2}$ is at least 2.
\end{theorem}

A positive answer is obtained recently in~\cite{CPW} by purely geometric methods. Results on rigidity of trinomial hypersurfaces in ${\mathbb K}^4$ are given in \cite[Section~5.4]{CM} and \cite[Theorem~9.1]{FMJ}.

\begin{theorem} \label{kpz}
Let $Q$ be a normal closed subvariety in ${\mathbb P}^{n-1}$, $H$ be a hyperplane section of $Q$ and $X$ be the affine cone over $Q$ in ${\mathbb K}^n$. Then $X$ is rigid if and only if $Q$ contains no $H$-polar cylinder.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}[Proof of Theorem~\ref{t2}]
Since the variety $X$ is factorial, every divisor on $Q$ is linearly equivalent to a multiple of $H$, see \cite[Exercise~6.3(c)]{H}. Thus any cylinder in $Q$ is automatically $H$-polar and
Theorem~\ref{kpz} shows that rigidity of $X$ is equivalent to absence of cylinders in $Q$.
We conclude that Theorem~\ref{t2} follows from Theorem~\ref{thmain}.
\end{proof}
